netsquid.nodes.network

This module provides the Network composite component, a class for managing the Nodes and Connections in a network.

class netsquid.nodes.network.Network(name, nodes=None)

Bases: Component

A component to help create and manage networks of nodes and connections.

A network is a composite component: it manages the Nodes and Connections of a network.

When connecting nodes using a connection component new ports are added to each nodes that are used to connect to either end of the connection.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the network for display purposes.

  • nodes (int or iterable of str or iterable of Node) – The nodes to add.

    • If nodes is an integer then this many are added to the network.

    • If an item in this iterable is a string it will create a new node with the string as name.

    • If an item in this iterable is a Node then this node will be added.

Examples

>>> import netsquid as ns
>>> from netsquid.nodes import Network
...
>>> network = Network(name="test_network")

Nodes can be added in multiple ways:

>>> from netsquid.nodes import Node
>>> from netsquid.components import  QuantumMemory, QuantumProcessor
...
>>> network.add_node("Huey")
>>> network.add_node(Node("Dewey"))
>>> nodes = network.add_nodes(nodes=4)
>>> for node in nodes:
...     node.add_subcomponent(QuantumProcessor("test_qproc"))
>>> nodes2 = network.add_nodes(nodes=("alice", "bob"))
>>> for node in nodes2:
...     node.add_subcomponent(QuantumMemory("qmem"))
>>> network.add_nodes(nodes=[Node("carl", qmemory=QuantumMemory("mem_carl")),
...                          Node("evan", qmemory=QuantumProcessor("mem_evan"))])
>>> for node in network.nodes.values():
...     print(node.name, node.qmemory)
Huey None
Dewey None
node2 QuantumProcessor(name='test_qproc')
node3 QuantumProcessor(name='test_qproc')
node4 QuantumProcessor(name='test_qproc')
node5 QuantumProcessor(name='test_qproc')
alice QuantumMemory(name='qmem')
bob QuantumMemory(name='qmem')
carl QuantumMemory(name='mem_carl')
evan QuantumProcessor(name='mem_evan')

Adding connections can also be done in a number of ways

>>> from netsquid.components import QuantumChannel, Channel
>>> from netsquid.nodes.connections import Connection
...
>>> network.add_connection("node3", "node4",
...                        connection=Connection("my_connection"))
>>> network.add_connection("alice", "bob",
...                        channel_to=QuantumChannel("quantum_channel"),
...                        label="quantum")
>>> network.add_connection("node2", "carl",
...                        channel_to=QuantumChannel("quantum_channel"),
...                        channel_from=Channel("Classical"), label="both")
>>> network.add_connection("alice", "bob", delay=4, bidirectional=True,
...                        label="label1")
>>> network.add_connection("node3", "node5", delay=4, bidirectional=False,
...                        label="label2")
>>> network.add_connection("node2", "carl", delay=(1, 4), label="label2")
>>> for conn in network.connections.values():
...     print(conn)
Connection(name='my_connection')
DirectConnection(name='conn|alice<->bob|quantum')
DirectConnection(name='conn|node2<->carl|both')
DirectConnection(name='conn|alice<->bob|label1')
DirectConnection(name='conn|node3<->node5|label2')
DirectConnection(name='conn|node2<->carl|label2')

The ports names that are used for the connection between nodes can be retrieved easily. We can now send messages across the network.

>>> port_2, port_c = network.get_connected_ports("node2", "carl", label="label2")
>>> node_2 = network.get_node("node2")
>>> node_c = network.get_node("carl")
>>> handler_2 = lambda m: print(f"Node2 received {m} at {ns.sim_time()}!")
>>> handler_c = lambda m: print(f"Carl received {m} at {ns.sim_time()}!")
>>> node_2.ports[port_2].bind_input_handler(handler_2)
>>> node_c.ports[port_c].bind_input_handler(handler_c)
>>> node_2.ports[port_2].tx_output("Hi Carl!")
>>> node_c.ports[port_c].tx_output("Hi Two!")
>>> x = ns.sim_run()
Carl received Message(items=['Hi Carl!'], header=None, ch_delta_time=1.0) at 1.0!
Node2 received Message(items=['Hi Two!'], header=None, ch_delta_time=4.0) at 4.0!
property nodes

Return all nodes in this network

Returns:

A Mapping with every Node of this network

Return type:

ConstrainedMapView

property connections

Return all connections in this network

Returns:

A Mapping with every Connection of this network

Return type:

ConstrainedMapView

add_nodes(nodes)

Add multiple nodes to this network

Parameters:

nodes (int or iterable of (str or Node)) – The nodes to add.

  • If nodes is an integer then nodes amount of Nodes are added to the network.

  • If an item in this iterable is a string it will create a new Node with the string as name

  • If an item in this iterable is a Node then this Node will be added

Returns:

The nodes that were added.

Return type:

list of Node

add_node(node)

Add a node to this network.

Parameters:

node (Node or str) – A node object or node name to add.

Returns:

The node that was added.

Return type:

Node

get_node(name)

Get a node of this network

Parameters:

name (str or Node) – name of the Node to get. Optionally it also accepts a Node. When a Node is given it will check if this Node belongs to the network, and throws an error if it is not.

Returns:

The node in this network with the given name

Return type:

Node

Examples

To get a list of nodes

>>> network = Network("My_Network")
>>> network.add_nodes(5)
>>> names = ["node0", "node4", "node3", "node2"]
>>> nodes = [network.get_node(name) for name in names]
>>> print(nodes)
[Node(name='node0'), Node(name='node4'), Node(name='node3'), Node(name='node2')]
remove_node(node)

Remove a node and all its connections from this network

Parameters:

node (str or Node) – The key of the node to be removed, or the node itself.

add_connection(node1, node2, connection=None, channel_to=None, channel_from=None, delay=None, bidirectional=None, label='', port_name_node1=None, port_name_node2=None)

Add a connection to the network

Connects two nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • node1 (Node or str) – First node to connect

  • node2 (Node or str) – Second node to connect

  • connection (Connection, optional) – The connection that will be placed between the two nodes

  • channel_to (Channel, optional) – The channel to be placed from node1 to node2. Ignored if connection parameter is given

  • channel_from (Channel, optional) – The channel to be placed from node2 to node1. Ignored if connection parameter is given

  • delay (int or float or tuple or list, optional) – If a single number this is the delay between node1 and node2. A regular Channel will be placed from node1 to node2 with this delay. If a tuple or list then will place two Channel between node1 and node2 with delays of delay[0] and delay[1] respectively. Ignored if connection, channel_to or channel_from parameter is given.

  • bidirectional (bool, optional) – If true, will also add a Channel from node2 to node1 with given delay. Only used when delay is a number.

  • label (str, optional) – Label to add to the channel, connection and port names. Used to be able to uniquely define connections between two nodes. Default is no label (empty string).

  • port_name_node1 (str, optional) – Custom port name to use for node1. If none given a default name will be created using the label

  • port_name_node2 (str, optional) – Custom port name to use for node2. If none given a default name will be created using the label

Returns:

  • str – Name of the connecting Port on node1.

  • str – Name of the connecting Port on node2.

Notes

Must provide at least one of connection, channel_to, channel_from or delay.

get_connection(node1, node2, label='')

Get a connection between two nodes of this network

Parameters:

  • node1 (str or Node) – First connected Node

  • node2 (str or Node) – Second connected Node

  • label (str, optional) – The label that was used when creating a connection between the nodes Default is no label (empty string)

Returns:

The connection between the two nodes with the given label, or None if none exists

Return type:

Connection or None

remove_connection(connection)

Removes a connection of this network

Parameters:

connection (str or Connection) – The key of the connection to be removed, or the connection it self.

Raises:

TypeError – If the connection isn’t a str or Connection.

Notes

Doesn’t raise any error if the connection wasn’t part of this network.

static connection_name(name1, name2, label='')

Gives a conventional connection name for a connection between two nodes

Parameters:

  • name1 (str) – Name of the first node

  • name2 (str) – Name of the second node

  • label (obj:str, optional) – Label for the connection. The purpose of labels is to distinguish multiple connections between the same two nodes. Default is no label (empty string)

Returns:

Name of this connection

Return type:

str

get_connected_ports(node1, node2, label='')

Get the port names that connect these two nodes.

If there is no connection present then None is returned for both port names.

Parameters:

  • node1 (str or Node) – First node

  • node2 (str or Node) – Second node

  • label (str, optional) – Label that was used when connecting these nodes. Default is not label (empty string)

Returns:

  • str or None – Name of the connecting Port on node1, or None if no connection present.

  • str or None – Name of the connecting Port on node2, or None if no connection present.

combine(other)

Combine two networks, adding all nodes of the other network to this network

Moves ALL subcomponents of the other network to this one. The other network is left empty (no nodes, no connections)

Parameters:

other (Network) – The nodes and connections of the other network to add to this network

exception netsquid.nodes.network.NetworkError

Bases: Exception

Error associated with a network
